content:
Diagnosis:	Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, T4bN1M1

Management:	Diagnosed March 2024 via FNA and core biopsy
	Emergency tracheostomy 15 March 2024 for airway compromise

Histology:	Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma with TP53 mutation

Current Situation:	Initial oncology assessment

I reviewed [redacted name] today who has unfortunately been diagnosed with advanced anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. She initially presented to ENT services in early March with a 6-week history of rapidly enlarging neck mass, progressive dysphagia, and increasing shortness of breath. She required emergency admission on 15 March 2024 with stridor, necessitating urgent tracheostomy.

Imaging shows a 12cm thyroid mass extending into the mediastinum with extensive local invasion, multiple pulmonary metastases up to 3cm, and widespread bone metastases including the thoracic spine and left hip. Molecular testing has identified a TP53 mutation.

Her symptoms have progressed significantly over the past month. She now reports severe neck pain requiring regular oxycodone, ongoing difficulty swallowing even liquids, and increasing fatigue. Her weight has dropped by 9kg. Her performance status has deteriorated to ECOG 3.

In her background, she has well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Current medications include regular oxycodone 20mg bd, insulin, amlodipine, and metformin. She lives with her husband who provides excellent support, though they are both struggling with the rapid progression of her condition.

Given the aggressive nature of her disease and poor performance status, I have had a detailed discussion about prognosis and treatment options. While the outlook is very challenging, she wishes to consider systemic therapy. I have explained the role of weekly paclitaxel and the possibility of concurrent radiotherapy if she stabilizes. We have discussed the significant risks of treatment in her current condition.

I have arranged urgent CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for formal baseline assessment, booked her for weekly paclitaxel to start next week pending blood results, and made an urgent referral to palliative care for symptom management. She will be reviewed twice weekly initially given the complexity of her situation. I have also arranged urgent radiotherapy assessment for consideration of palliative radiotherapy to the neck mass.
